What's the difference between taxi and private hire?

Understanding the difference is important - different rules and licences apply.

Feature Hackney Carriage (Taxi) Private Hire Vehicle
Street hailing ‚úì Can be hailed in street ‚úó Pre-booking only
Taxi ranks ‚úì Can wait at designated ranks ‚úó Cannot use ranks (criminal offence)
Booking method Hailing, ranks, or pre-booking Must be pre-booked through operator
Fare control Maximum fares set by council (tariff) Agreed between operator and customer
Taximeter Mandatory - must be approved and calibrated Optional
Signage May display 'taxi' or 'cab' roof sign Cannot use 'taxi' or 'cab' signage
Plates White/black plates Yellow plates
üö´
Critical difference: Private hire vehicles accepting street hailing are operating illegally - the journey is uninsured and the driver is committing a criminal offence.

Can I have both licences?

Yes - many drivers hold both hackney carriage and private hire driver licences (dual licence). This gives maximum flexibility. However, when driving a specific vehicle, you must follow the rules for that vehicle type.
